ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: A really, really interesting line-up of speakers, and a great depth of knowledge from the other students, from Hank, and from the TAs, made this course really valuable. I wish there was more of a mechanism to translate each speaker's presentation to more of a frame-work or big-picture sense of campaigns - somehow, I felt like I was lacking the vocabulary or framework to connect the dots (though this may have just been me).
n/a

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The different speakers!

A lot of the impact for me depended on whether or not the speakers were willing to open up their presentations to conversations, instead of just talking at us. This was not the fault of the instructor or the course design, simply that some speakers were better than others. For me, the best aspect of this course were the real and engaging dialogues amongst all us students and the visiting speakers. This happened 3 or 4 times.

The overarching fact is that there is not another course like this at FES. There are courses about stakeholder engagement, courses in which you could choose to analyze a campaign, but no other course that takes as it's core directive the study and implementation of successful (and occasionally unsuccessful) campaigns. This is a speaker driven course, so the quality of the course fluctuates with the quality of its speakers. When the speakers are great, so is the course. The other major positive is Hank's willingness to receive and adjust to feedback.
Learning from the speakers, and hearing other students' presentations.
When a lecturer was engaging it was great.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The workshops. The lecture part was generally good, but the hands-on part was usually too short toproduce anything valuable.

I would try to intentionally facilitate space for more organic conversation to take place. The "assigned hotseat" questioneers were good to get the ball rolling, but it felt overly structured sometimes and only a few people tended to dominate the conversation.

Some of the speakers weren't great, or didn't speak to campaigns broadly, instead getting lost in the particulars of their own causes. I would say the course got off to a rocky start but improved over time.

I wish the kinds of discussions we had around the presentations occurred earlier in the course. The last-minute canceling of some of the longer readings was also frustrating, after having budgeted time and money towards purchasing and reading them - communicating these cancellations earlier would have been appreciated.
More guided reading on critical thinking about campaigns and strategy, not just the background readings on weekly topics from guests.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: n/a

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I might be trying to start a campaign, so this course was directly relevant.
This course didn't at first, but it turned out to be very helpful in thinking about how people conceptualize messaging.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took this course because I'd heard good things about it and I wanted the exposure to campaigners.
It seemed like a practical exploration of how to accomplish environmental goals.
I needed a credit, but turns out the class was great.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: YES!!
Yes, I feel that I did get a lay-of-the-land on a wide variety of environmental campaigns, their methods and platforms, failures and successes. That knowledge itself is really useful.
yes.
Yes and no - I think I got an inspiring grounding in how a campaign works, but I still feel like I'm missing some crucial vocabulary about the details of campaign processes.
Yes, went higher than expected.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was really a work duo. We had the option to work as a pair and chose to, so it went quite well.
n/a

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Ask the speakers questions that matter to you as you craft your own theory of change.
Think really carefully about your final project.
Great class and Hank is a v good instructor. It was a bit late in the day but really valuable for anyone in environmentalism.
